Upskilling and reskilling in the Ai era

By benjination2@gmail.com • 9/17/2025
History has repeatedly demonstrated that software development is among the most dynamic and innovative fields in existence. The recent surge of powerful artificial intelligence has not merely disrupted the industry, it has fundamentally redefined it. Convincing AI tools have upended the traditional landscape, instilling a new level of urgency and concern in the minds of entry-level software engineers everywhere. Routine coding tasks that once served as the proving ground for interns and junior developers are now handled swiftly and efficiently by AI. While this automation accelerates productivity, it also raises the bar dramatically for new graduates entering the field.

Today, upskilling and reskilling are no longer optional or reserved for underperformers, they are essential for anyone hoping to keep pace with the relentless evolution of software creation. As Nate Swanner highlights in his essay, “How AI Will Impact Software Development in 2025 and Beyond,” artificial intelligence is reshaping every rung of the engineering ladder. AI has left the realm of science fiction and become an indispensable co-pilot, capable of generating vast amounts of code, identifying architectural flaws, and flagging performance issues before they escalate. Tasks like basic bug fixes and boilerplate coding, once the bread and butter of junior engineers, can now be accomplished in minutes, not hours. As a result, the expectations for entry-level engineers have shifted dramatically. Instead of focusing on repetitive work, they are now expected to contribute to creative design, high-level problem-solving, and strategic decision-making, responsibilities that were once the exclusive domain of senior engineers.

While AI has relieved new engineers of some traditional burdens, it has also introduced a new set of challenges and responsibilities. Mastery of AI is now a prerequisite, not a bonus. Engineers must know how to deploy AI ethically, safely, and effectively. They must recognize that, like any tool, AI is fallible, it can make mistakes, draw from imprecise sources, and require human oversight. New engineers are expected to guide, refine, and validate AI output, which demands not only technological fluency but also a deep understanding of business objectives, skills traditionally reserved for senior staff and project managers.

Industry voices confirm these sweeping changes. Miles Jennings echoes Swanner’s perspective, emphasizing that while the nature of entry-level opportunities is changing, they are not disappearing. On the contrary, new engineers who embrace AI will find themselves fast-tracked into more meaningful and exciting roles, bypassing years of rote work. The analogy is clear. Just as “calculators” once referred to people before becoming ubiquitous tools, today’s engineers must evolve, adopting new skills and responsibilities as AI transforms the profession.

Steve Lohr, in his New York Times article “A.I. Is Prompting an Evolution, Not an Extinction, for Coders,” reinforces this view. AI is not eliminating developers, it is redefining what it means to be one. Rather than replacing human ingenuity, AI is amplifying it, shifting the focus from manual coding to the orchestration of AI-driven development. Productivity is soaring, but so are the expectations. The future belongs to those who can collaborate with AI, guiding its output and aligning it with broader business goals. In this new era, adaptability and a willingness to lead alongside AI are the keys to success in software engineering.

References:

1 Swanner, N. (2024, December 18). How ai will impact software development in 2025 and Beyond. How AI Will Impact Software Development in 2025 and Beyond. https://www.dice.com/career-advice/how-ai-will-impact-software-development-in-2025-and-beyond

2 Jennings, M. (2025, March 12). Future of software engineering in an AI-Driven World. Future of Software Engineering in an AI-Driven World. https://blog.getaura.ai/future-of-software-engineering-in-an-ai-driven-world

3 Lohr, S. (2025, February 20). A.I. is prompting an evolution, not an extinction, for coders - The New York Times. A.I. Is Prompting an Evolution, Not Extinction, for Coders. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/20/business/ai-coding-software-engineers.html
